      fishing and just standing on the shore like an idiot." - Steven

DID YOU KNOW?Julius Caesar and Napoleon Bonaparte both 
      suffered from epilepsy. 

TONIGHT ON THE CBS EVENING NEWSHere is 
      an early preview of what we are planning for tonight’s CBS EVENING NEWS 
      from Anchor and Managing Editor, Katie Couric… Hi, 
      everyone, Tens of thousands draped themselves in Iraqi flags and 
      marched through the streets of two Shiite holy cities today to mark the 
      fourth anniversary of Baghdad's fall to U.S. troops. The show of force was 
      orchestrated by the radical Shiite cleric Moqtada al Sadr, who proved that 
      he commands an enormous following among Iraq's largest religious group. 
      Martin Seemungal is in Baghdad, and will have more on this story 
      tonight. Iran announced a dramatic expansion of uranium 
      enrichment, saying it has begun operating 3,000 centrifuges. That's nearly 
      10 times the previously known number, and is in defiance of U.N. demands 
      that it halt the program or face increased sanctions. We will have a 
      reality check on the real threat from Iran. President Bush is 
      making another push for immigration reform. He visited the U.S.-Mexico 
      border to tout a guest worker program for immigrants. With up to 12 
      million illegal immigrants in the U.S., lawmakers haven't agreed on how to 
      uphold the law without disrupting lives, eroding the work force and 
      risking political upheaval. Kelly Cobiella will report from the 
      desert stretch where Arizona and Mexico meet. Border agents there say they 
      are pelted with rocks and the victims of assault from smugglers. In fact, 
      there have been more assaults against agents in the Yuma sector this year 
      than all of last year. At any one time in this country, as many as 
      100,000 people are suffering from heart failure, but only about 2,000 
      people a year receive heart transplants. For a long time, doctors were 
      focused on developing a heart pump as a bridge to when a new heart becomes 
      available. But a new device is showing it can be more than just a bridge. 
      Our contributing medical correspondent, CNN's Dr. Sanjay Gupta, 
      will tell you about this. There's also a growing uproar over radio 
      host Don Imus' racially charged comments about the Rutgers University 
      women's basketball team. Despite his on-air apologies, the calls continue 
      for him to be fired from his syndicated morning program, after his 
      racially charged comments. Imus appeared on the Rev. Al Sharpton's radio 
      program today and issued another apology. Richard Schlesinger will 
      have this report, and will discuss the FCC's regulations as well. 
      Finally, for computer researcher Zombie Bell even his morning walk 
      to work is part of a grand experiment in digitizing and remembering 
      everything. The little camera around his neck takes a picture every 30 
      seconds or so, and a sound recorder rolls non-stop. Bell is saving his 
      whole life on computer, from childhood certificates to all his medical 
      records. John Blackstone will have his story. I hope 
      to see you tonight. Katie For more information on these 
      stories, please click on the following links: Iraqi Shiites 
      Hit Streets To Protest U.S. Click Here Bush Renews Push For 
      Immigration Reform Click Here And here's a look at 
      one of the stories we’re working on for Tuesday’s 
      broadcast:   
      Dr. Jon LaPook reports on how stem cell research 
      could revolutionize the treatment of juvenile diabetes. That story and 
      much more, Tuesday, on the CBS Evening News. If you would like more information on any of these 
      stories or the broadcast, please click on the following address and e-mail 
      us: evening@cbsnews.com 

TONIGHT ON DAVID 
      LETTERMANDave sits down with 2008 Democratic Presidential 
      Candidate Sen. Barack Obama... Plus, actress Halle Berry! 

TUESDAY
MORNING ON THE EARLY SHOWHarry 
      Smith, Hannah Storm, Julie Chen, and Russ 
      Mitchell anchor THE EARLY SHOW from New York. Dave 
      Price will bring us the weather. Along with the top news of 
      the day, we will also have the following stories: ANNA 
      NICOLE'S SISTER: NEW BOOK, PT. 1: In the first of an exclusive 
      two-part interview, Donna Hogan, sister of Anna Nicole Smith, will join us 
      to talk about the death of the blonde bombshell. Tuesday morning, in her 
      first interview since her sister's death, Hogan will join us to discuss 
      her unauthorized biography of the late actress entitled, Train Wreck: 
      The Life and Death of Anna Nicole Smith. LOU DOBBS: In 
      the first of his new weekly commentaries, Lou Dobbs, anchor and managing 
      editor of CNN's Lou Dobbs Tonight, will join 
      us. TWO HEROES who have 
      made a difference: In another installment of 
      our special series, Second Act, we will take a look at Jim Laws, a 
      cardiologist from Ohio, and Ed Artis, who began his career as a juvenile 
      car thief. Ed soon found himself in the Army, where he learned to get 
      things done in hostile places. It was not long after that he began his 
      life as a freelance humanitarian. When Ed met Jim in Moscow in 1993, the 
      two knew they were destined for great things. In Moscow, Ed became a 
      Knight of Malta, a humanitarian order that dates back to the Crusades. 
      Jim, already a Knight for his Community Service, became intrigued by Ed's 
      courage. The two formed Knightsbridge and raise money like any charity, 
      but their ability to distribute large quantities of aid and medicine 
      directly to the people at the end of the line is what sets them apart. Ed 
      Artis and Jim Laws have risked their lives distributing tens of millions 
      of dollars worth of aid to the needy, and they couldn't be happier. We'll 
      hear their amazing story Tuesday morning. For information on 
      how you can help Ed Artis and Jim Laws on their next humanitarian mission 
      to Darfur, go to: OneDollar4Darfur Click Here For 
      information on the documentary Beyond the Call featuring Ed Artis 
      and Jim Laws, go to: Beyond The Call The Movie Click Here
CHRIS KIMBALL: EASY MAKE AHEAD RECIPES: Cook's 
      Illustrated is the definitive source for all your questions in the 
      kitchen. And what they have found out is that preparing a delicious meal 
      does not have to be a huge undertaking. Now, their latest book, The 
      Best Make-Ahead Recipe, offers closet o three hundred easy recipes 
      that you can prepare ahead of time. How can you cook now to save time 
      later? The Best Make-Ahead Recipe is a cookbook for people who want 
      homemade meals, but don't always have the time to pull a meal together on 
      a weeknight. These recipes are ones you can prep in advance - they store 
      well, and cook well. The book is full of advice on freezing, using 
      leftovers, and other simple tricks. Tuesday morning, Cook's 
      Illustrated founder and editor Chris Kimball will join us with recipes 
      from the exciting new make-ahead recipe cookbook - a must for any cook 
      concerned with time. HOW SAFE IS YOUR DRINKING WATER?: A 
      new study to be released on Tuesday takes a look at the quality of 
      drinking water across the country. How safe is your drinking water? The 
      results may surprise you. CBS News Transportation and Consumer Safety 
      Correspondent Nancy Cordes will join us with more. She'll also shed 
      some light on the best filtration products that are available. 
      MARTIN SHORT: On Tuesday, the original cast recording of 
      Martin Short: Fame Becomes Me, will be released. Joining us to 
      celebrate the release of his album will be the very funny Martin Short! 
      CONSUMER REPORTS: BEST AND WORST APPLIANCES: Well it turns 
      out that paying more for your kitchen appliances does not guarantee 
      reliability. The Consumer Reports Annual Product Reliability Survey 
      identifies the most and least reliable product brands and the results just 
      may surprise you. Tuesday morning, we'll take a look at how some of the 
      more popular kitchen ranges, refrigerators, dishwashers and microwaves 
      fared in the recent survey. Mandy Walker, Senior Editor of Consumer 
      Reports, will join us with a roundup of the latest. SHIA 
      LEBEOUF ON DISTURBIA: Actor Shia LaBeouf is one of Hollywood's 
      hottest rising stars. He first gained attention at age thirteen with his 
      Emmy winning role on the Disney series Even Stevens. He parlayed 
      that into a successful film career with a starring role in Holes, 
      and was soon teaming up with A-listers like Will Smith in I, Robot 
      and Keanu Reeves in Constantine. Now, LaBeouf has three films being 
      released in the next three months, including Disturbia, which opens 
      this Friday. The rising star will join us Tuesday morning to talk about 
      his new film and newfound success. FURNITURE AND TAXES: 
      With tax season upon us, many of us are looking for an easy way to reduce 
      some of our out-of-pocket costs. Jennifer Litwin, author of Furniture 
      Hot Spots and Best Furniture Buying Tips Ever!, and a 
      contributor to Consumer's Digest magazine, recommends donating 
      gently used furniture to save money on income taxes. So how can you decide 
      what items will make the most sizable contributions? Jennifer Litwin will 
      join us with advice. If you would like more information on any of 
      these stories or the broadcast, please click on the following address and 
      e-mail us: earlyshow@cbs.com
